text: hey everybody thomas joseph here and I
know that we've all experienced this
kitchen conundrum you're ready to make
that batch of cookies or you're ready to
make some other sweet treat and you
reach for your brown sugar and you find
out that it's as hard as a rock what are
you going to do well today I'm going to
show you how you can magically soften
brown sugar back to its original texture
so that you can use it in recipes and
also how to store it properly so that
you are ready to bake whatever you need
to with your brown sugar any day of the
week so starting with this hard block of
brown sugar this is light brown sugar
but the same method applies here for
dark brown sugar as well place it in a
glass bowl and you're going to need a
small glass bowl of water as well so now
the trick here is using the microwave so
right into the microwave and now I'm
going to microwave on HIGH power for 20
second intervals and it will probably
take anywhere between 40 and 60 seconds
in total
so it's been 20 seconds using a fork see
if you can chip away at the brown sugar
if it needs more time you won't be able
to break it up into clumps so this needs
more time I'm going to return it for
another 20 seconds and another 20
seconds after that if need be
so our brown sugar has been in the
microwave for about 90 seconds and what
you can see is it starts to soften as
soon as the water in that little dish
starts boiling it transfers the moisture
into the brown sugar all that steam
that's being created now if you have any
clumps that are still hard
you can return these to the microwave
and you're sure to get this wonderful
consistency it just takes a little bit
of time but this is perfectly usable for
your cookie recipe now to prevent this
from happening so you don't end up with
this conundrum all you need to do is
store your brown sugar in an airtight
container in addition to the actual
vessel you're storing it in is add a
little piece of bread and this is just
some white bread maybe a quarter of a
slice of white bread would work here a
lot of people like to use a thin slice
of apple and also a marshmallow a
store-bought marshmallow will work just
as well so any of these three items
would work in keeping your brown sugar
nice and soft and the reason that it
does is because the excess moisture
within the slice of bread within the
Apple or the marshmallow is transferred
or absorbed by the sugar and that's what
keeps it nice and soft make sure that
you seal the lid so it's airtight and
you will have perfect usable brown sugar
for any recipe that you need it for and
your kitchen conundrum whether it's this
or that is solved enjoy if you have any
kitchen conundrums that you need solved
baking or otherwise write in the comment
section below or reach out to us using
the hashtag kitchen conundrums and we
will solve whatever kitchen problems you
may have
